Award.AwardTitle: Hybrid Composites for Light-Controlled CO and Silver Delivery to Malignant Sites and Infection
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical:

This award by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research to University of California Santa Cruz is for the development of biocompatible nanoparticles with photoactive carbon monoxide-donors that can elicit either cell recovery or death depending on the concentration. Although carbon monoxide (CO) is commonly known as the 'silent killer', in recent years salutary effects of low doses of this noxious gas have been demonstrated in oxygen-deprived tissues (as in stroke or heart attack) and in organ transplants. This surprising discovery has prompted the research community to develop new delivery modes in which controlled doses of CO can be delivered to biological targets. Because CO induces programmed cell death in cancer cells at elevated levels, attempts are also being made to deliver high doses of CO selectively at malignant sites to combat cancer. This research focuses on development of silica-based nanoparticles with photoactive CO-donors that can elicit either cell recovery or death depending on the concentration. Entrapment of the CO-donor within the porous nanoparticles will ensure very little side effects from the byproducts of the drug. Research will also be directed toward development of a cellulose-based bandage material that incorporates another salutary agent, namely silver. The bandage material will be impregnated with fluorescent silver compounds to track the sustained delivery of silver to infected wounds, often encountered on burn victims. This new delivery mode will allow monitoring of the wound healing process with time and amount of silver applied to the wound site. Together, these composite materials will provide new and convenient ways to treat inflammation, transplant failures, malignancies, and chronic wound infections.

Technical:

In the first part of the project, photoactive carbon monoxide (CO)-donating metal complexes designed in the Principal Investigator's (PI) group, will be incorporated into the pores of 50-70 nm mesoporous silica-based nanoparticles for on-demand CO delivery to: a) provide protection to oxidatively-damaged sites (as in ischemia and balloon angioplasty) under low-flux regimen; and b) eradicate malignant cells (colon or breast cancer) under high dose conditions. Characterization of the nanoparticle will utilize the expertise of the co-PI's group while the biological assays will be completed in the PI's laboratory. Confinement of the CO sources in the nanoparticles will ensure very little toxicity from the byproducts of the CO-donors in each case and the enhanced uptake of the nanoparticles will allow preferential kill of cancer cells in the latter application. The second part of the project is intended to develop carboxymethyl cellulose bandage materials with impregnated fluorescent silver compounds to track silver delivery to infected wounds, often seen in burn victims. This research effort will use designed silver complexes of fluorescent ligands for slow release of silver (to avoid precipitation as is the case with ordinary silver salts) and tracking the extent of drug delivery through turn-on or turn-off of fluorescence. Participation in these projects will allow the graduate and undergraduate students (some from underrepresented groups) to acquire experience in a wide range of fields including chemical synthesis, biochemistry, materials science, drug-design and assays, and cell biology. Successful completion of the work will afford new biocompatible composites that could be employed to deliver CO (a difficult gas to handle in hospital settings) and silver for various high-impact biomedical applications such as the treatment of infections, vasorelaxation, cytoprotection from oxidative and inflammatory damage, and cancer therapy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the past few years, the surprising discovery of salutary effects of low levels of carbon monoxide (CO) in mammalian physiology has prompted research activity in search of suitable CO donors as therapeutics. However, the preferential pro-apoptotic effects of low doses of carbon monoxide (CO) in hyperproliferative and cancer cells have only recently been realized and the high sensitivity of cancer cells to CO has so far not been exploited in combating cancer. In this research we developed metal carbonyl-incorporated mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) that release CO on-demand upon exposure to low power visible light. Use of MSNs as the delivery vehicle allows more selective delivery of CO-donating pro-drugs to the malignant cells compared to administration of the free pro-drugs due to enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effects. In addition, the CO-releasing molecules remain anchored in the biocompatible host and cause minimal toxicity. Such control and biocompatibility is not possible with either CO gas or current CO-releasing pro-drugs. We have carefully evaluated the utility of the biocompatible MSNs in eradication of cancer cells.

Outcomes

(a) Successful eradication of human breast cancer cells through CO delivery with Al-MCM-41 nanoparticles packed with a designed photoCORM

      Any phototherapy of cancer requires delivery of the drug upon illumination with visible/infrared light. We have been successful in designing photoCORMs that could deliver CO upon such illumination for quite sometime. In this funded period, we have synthesized Mn(I) carbonyl complexes that rapidly release CO upon exposure to low-power (5-10 mW) visible light and cause eradication of cancer cells in a dose-dependent fashion. For example the designed photoCORM [MnBr(azpy)(CO)3] (azpy = 2-phenylazopyridine) shows significant phototoxicity toward two malignant cell lines HeLa and human breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231) under the control of visible light illumination.  In our next step, we incorporated a fluorescent photoCORM namely, [Re(CO)3(pbt)(PPh3)](CF3SO3] ({Re-CO} hereafter; pbt = 2-(2-pyridyl)-benzo-thiazole) in the pores of 100 nm Al-MCM-41 MSNs (final Re content: 1%) to check their utility in eradication of cancer cells. Strong entrapment of the positively-charged photoCORM [Re(CO)3(pbt)(PPh3)]+ within the pores of the MSNs was confirmed by various spectroscopic measurements and leaching experiments in biological buffers (Fig.1. left panel). The MSNs were readily endocytosed by human breast cancer cells, a fact readily visualized by the intense orange luminescence (excitation = 400 nm) of the loaded cells (Fig.1. right panel).  Because the Re(I) photoCORM exhibits a ?turn OFF? of its luminescence upon release of one CO ligand, we were also able to track the CO photorelease event from the MSNs in cellular matrix. Results of cellular viability assay with MTT clearly indicated a dose-dependent death of cancer cells.

Broader Impact: These results clearly established the utility of composites like {Re-CO}@Al-MCM-41 MSNs in eradication of cancer cells through light-triggered CO delivery. CO has recently been shown to sensitize cancer cells to chemotherapy as well as induces apoptosis in prostate, colon, pancreas and other cancer cells. Our results demonstrate the feasibility of CO carriers like {Re-CO}@Al-MCM-41 MSNs in treating localized malignancies such as colon cancer through CO delivery by first selective accumulation of the MSNs in cancer cells (exploiting the EPR effect) and then illumination of the colon through fiber optic-based illumination (much like colonoscopy). In addition, this work provided the first hint toward the possibility of ?tracking? the CO delivery event through fluorescence spectroscopy (thiswork was highlighted on the cover of Chemistry of Materials, December 22, 2015 issue (Fig.1. left panel).

(b) Construction of silver(I)-loaded cellulose-based wound dressing

 Rapid precipitation of bioactive Ag+ in cellular matrices and/or insolubility of silver salts such as silver sulfadiazine often limit the delivery of silver to thwart infections at burn wounds. In order to design slow-releasing silver-containing bandage materials, we have initiated syntheses of new fluorescent silver complexes that slowly break down in biological fluids to afford sustainable doses of Ag+. Side by side, we have now identified the right conditions for gelation of carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC, average Mw 250,000 or more) and prepared new carboxymethyl cellulose-based robust hydrogel patches with the right water content for improved shelf life. Recently, we have incorporated a silver(I) complex  [Ag(ImD)2]ClO4  (ImD = Dansyl imidazole) within such a CMC hydrogel patch that allows slow release of silver. This complex exhibits MIC values of 2.3 and 4.7 mg/mL against E. coli and S. aureus, respectively. A complete occlusive dressing has finally been constructed with the Ag(ImD)CMC (1% Ag) pad sealed between a sterile mesh gauze (as bottom layer) and a rayon-based surgical tape(as the top layer) (Fig. 2, left panel). This dressing displays sustained delivery of silver onto a skin and soft tissue infection (SSTI) model and causes effective eradication of bacterial  loads  within 24 h. The transfer of the antibiotic silver complex is readily visualized by the observed fluorescence that overlays precisely with the kill zone (Fig. 2 right panel).
